headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Welcome to the Fiserv Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In addition, there are supplemental materials that will be referenced on today's call available at the company's website. To access those materials, go to the comp
componenttext: Welcome to the Fiserv Fourth Quarter 2009 Earnings Conference Call. [Operator Instructions] In addition, there are supplemental materials that will be referenced on today's call available at the company's website. To access those materials, go to the company's website at www.fiserv.com and click on the Access Presentation link on the home page. The call is expected to last about an hour. [Operator Instructions] And now, I would like to turn the call over to Jeff Yabuki, President and CEO of Fiserv.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Great, thank you. Good afternoon and thanks for joining us for our fourth quarter 2009 earnings conference call. With me on the call today is our Chief Financial Officer, Tom Hirsch. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements within the mea
componenttext: Great, thank you. Good afternoon and thanks for joining us for our fourth quarter 2009 earnings conference call. With me on the call today is our Chief Financial Officer, Tom Hirsch. Our remarks today will include forward-looking statements within the meaning of the Private Securities Litigation Reform Act of 1995. We will make forward-looking statements about, among other matters, adjusted revenue growth, adjusted earnings per share, adjusted operating margins, free cash flow, sales pipelines, and our strategic initiative, Fiserv 2.0. Forward-looking statements may differ materially from actual results and are subject to a number of risks and uncertainties. Please refer to our earnings release, which can be found on our website at fiserv.com, for a discussion of these risk factors. You should also refer to our earnings release for an explanation of the non-GAAP financial measures discussed in this conference call and for a reconciliation of those measures to the nearest applicable GAAP measure. These non-GAAP measures are indicators that management uses to provide additional, meaningful comparisons between current results and prior-reported results and as a basis for planning and forecasting for future periods.Let me say upfront that we are pleased with our results for the quarter. Adjusted internal revenue growth was back into positive territory, capitalizing on the strong fundamentals of our business model. Earlier in the year, we shared our belief that revenue growth momentum was building, which would produce quarter-over-quarter improvements and positive revenue growth by year end. As you've seen by our results today, we delivered on that expectation. That said, 2009 was, by any measure, a challenge. We began the year with an unprecedented level of economic uncertainty. The financial services sector, was a bit weaker to the point where some industry pundits question the long-term viability of the entire system. Through the economic turbulence, we were confident and remain so today, in the long-term prospects of the financial services industry and also that the structure of the U.S. banking system would persevere. I will comment about the industry environment later in the call. Our confidence in the longevity of the industry was matched by the strength of our business model and the diversity of our client base. We finished 2009 on a high note, with strong fourth quarter financial performance and December sales results that were the highest in the company's history. Each of these markers is an important sign leading to higher levels of sustainable revenue and earnings growth. Our 2% adjusted internal revenue growth rate in the quarter was at the top end of our recent guidance, with total GAAP revenue also increasing 2% to $1.06 billion.Adjusted earnings per share in the quarter were $0.94 and free cash flow in the quarter exceeded $160 million. Despite market conditions, we grew adjusted earnings per share 10% in 2009 to a record level of $3.66. Free cash flow of $668 million was also an all-time high. And as important, free cash flow per share was up sharply to $4.30.We clearly felt the impact of the environment on our top line, with adjusted revenue declining just under 1% for the year. This decline included headwinds such as significant reductions in termination fees, which were indicative of the market challenges. Full year adjusted operating margin increased more than 100 basis points due to favorable shifts in our business mix and strong execution of our operational effectiveness initiatives. Based on strong performance in the quarter and for the full year, we increased the amount of our discretionary profit-sharing as compared to 2008. As Tom will explain in a moment, the incremental accrual negatively impacted our consolidated margin in the quarter by about 100 basis points. We ask our associates do our work hard as ever in 2009 while managing costs extraordinarily well, faced up after the challenge, delivered strong results and continue to partner with our clients.You will recall that we had a three key enterprise priorities in 2009. First, to meet our earnings commitments while maintaining capital flexibility. Next, to continue the integration efforts with an increased focus on revenue opportunities and product innovation. And third, to enhance our go-to-market approach, leading to increased sales results to new and existing clients.To our first priority, we delivered 2009 earnings within our original guidance range. For the year, we grew adjusted earnings to a record level of $3.66 per share and increased adjusted operating margin by 110 basis points. Our earnings growth is particularly notable in light of the significant decline in high-margin termination fees and float income versus 2008.We delivered $668 million in free cash flow during 2009, up 11% for the year and at the very top of our original guidance. We also actively managed our capital in 2009 through the repurchase of 4.1 million shares of stock and $475 million of debt repayment. We continue to focus on our second priority of delivering market facing integration. We had a strong finish to the year, generating over $40 million of integrated sales in the quarter and $117 million for the full year. This was 30% more than our 2009 objective of $90 million and 36% higher than 2008. Our numerous sales wins, many of which were competitive takeaways, validates that Fiserv clients want the integration of our market-leading products such as online banking, bill payment, source capture and debit processing, with our industry-leading account processing solutions.These client benefits were evident across our payment solutions with 407 bill payment wins and 215 new debit clients this year. Over the last two years since the acquisition of CheckFree, we have added 1,370 new client relationships in these two strategic payment solutions, and we still have a significant amount of penetration opportunity ahead.We also capitalized on several product innovation opportunities in 2009. We invested in Acumen, a powerful new account processing platform for credit unions, which has experienced tremendous success in Canada, winning a substantial majority of all of the deals at play. Importantly, we recently won our first U.S. client, Christian Community Credit Union, a $500 million credit union, that is within the larger segment of that market where we expect Acumen to gain material share over the next several years.  We also continued to invest next generation products such as Mobile Money, P2P [person-to-person] payments and analytics as a service, all of which are center stage in the dialogue with our clients.We continued to optimize our expense structure in 2009, generating over $100 million of cost savings well ahead of our $60 million target for the year. The majority of the above target savings came from better-than-expected cost synergies resulting from the CheckFree acquisition. While we are ahead of our original timetable with our cost saves, we continued to identify new opportunities to optimize our overall cost structure. The over performance and cost saves have provided a larger opportunity to invest during a dynamic time in the market. We are committed to making strategic investments and products today that will create value for clients and secure our market leadership position for years to come.To our third priority, as we shared with you at Investor Day, we believe we can to improve our growth rate by changing how we go to market. We made important progress, which is reflected in our sales results and in particular, in the fourth quarter this year. We won several large integrated account processing transactions during the year, such as American Savings Bank and Tesco Bank, which are illustrative proved points of our market strategy. Importantly, the changes that we have made over the last several years made these types of deals possible, and we expect there will be even more market recognition of our strategy moving forward.In addition to the steps we took last year, we have made organizational changes in 2010, deferred to capitalize on significant market opportunity, with increased speed, agility and focus. As part of these changes, we've added leadership talent to the organization and also reconfigured our go-to-market approach. First, we created a single global sales organization, which will include new sales and enterprise account management. Tom Warsop, who as you know, was one of our Group Presidents, will assume the Chief Sales Officer role and lead our go-to-market efforts. In addition to Tom's three years at Fiserv, he spent nearly 18 years at EDS [Electronic Data Systems} in a variety of leadership roles, with the majority of his time focused on leading their efforts in large, complex enterprise sales and also service delivery across the financial services industry. As we witnessed at Investor Day, Tom brings a high degree of experience, expertise and passion to the position. Our organization is excited and enthusiastic about these changes as they recognize the power of going to market as one Fiserv.  We expect these changes to lead to increased win rates, as well as higher levels of product penetration across the mid and large tiers of the market. We also combined the majority of our payments in Internet Banking businesses under one group, which will be led by Steve Olsen. We believe that the convergence and payments technologies, along with our focus to unlock the material DDA-based [demand deposit account] payments opportunity, warranted the combination of these important market-facing solutions.Our Account Processing and related businesses will now be led by Steve Tait, who joined Fiserv in November 2009. Steve brings over 25 years of progressive senior leadership experience, with roles at Xerox, the Gartner Group and was most recently, President and CEO of RSM McGladrey. Steve has a deep understanding of technology and services, which will serve us well in leading this important area of the company.Mike Giannoni, who most recently led our Investment Services business, becomes the Group President, leading our Financial Institutions group. In addition to Investment Services, this area includes risks, lending and revenue enhancement solutions, which are delivered around the world. We are excited about the changes we are sharing with you today. We believe they will have a positive impact on our results in 2010 and well beyond. We are focused on achieving heightened levels of profitable growth, and we will continue to lead in a way that delivers superior results for our clients, our shareholders and our associates.  Now, let me turn the call over to Tom for a deeper dive on the financial results.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Jeff, and good afternoon, everyone. I am pleased to report that we closed the divestitures of our Loan Fulfillment Solutions business and the remaining portion of our Trust business, known as ask Fiserv ISS [Investment Support Services] in the fou
componenttext: Thanks, Jeff, and good afternoon, everyone. I am pleased to report that we closed the divestitures of our Loan Fulfillment Solutions business and the remaining portion of our Trust business, known as ask Fiserv ISS [Investment Support Services] in the fourth quarter. These dispositions complete the majority of the work that we started several years ago to reshape your company.As we shared at Investor Day, this repositioning has allowed us to focus our resources on a more tightly integrated set of complementary businesses with attractive scale, network economics and better long-term growth prospects. So for my discussion today, I will refer to the supplemental information included in the slide presentation. You will note this quarter that our results are a bit easier to understand, as the dispositions and one-time items are largely behind us.Our fourth quarter adjusted internal revenue grew 2% over the prior year, which is at the top end of our guidance for the quarter. Total GAAP revenue also increased 2% to $1.06 billion. Adjusted EPS in the quarter was $0.94, up 6% compared with the prior year and excludes a $0.04 per share per benefit, primarily related to the reversal of a pre-acquisition liability associated with the acquisition of CheckFree.Adjusted operating income was $283 million for the quarter and $1.11 billion for the year. Our year-to-date adjusted operating margin of 28.7% increased to 110 basis points compared to 2008, due to an improved business mix and operating efficiencies.Adjusted operating margin in the fourth quarter was 28.1%, a decline of 20 basis points in 2008. As Jeff mentioned, given our strong performance in the quarter and the year, we elected to double the amount of discretionary profit-sharing for all eligible associates in 2009, which resulted in approximately $10 million of incremental expense in the quarter.  This item, which negatively impacted margin by roughly 100 basis points in the quarter, was intended to reward the strong performance of our associates and to partially offset compensation actions instituted in 2009. Turning to Slide 6, adjusted revenue for the year was down slightly, just under 1%, as our business model showed its resiliency during one of the most challenging years that the financial industry has ever seen. This resiliency is the product of our high level of recurring revenue, large client base, long-term client contracts and the mission-critical nature of our products and services. Not withstanding the environment, the quality of our earnings has never been better. We generated record adjusted earnings of $3.66 per share, an increase of 10% over the prior year and expanded operating margin by more than 100 basis points compared with 2008. In fact, since 2006, we have sustainably improved company operating margin by almost 600 basis points from 22.9% to 28.7%.Our earnings and margin growth in 2009 is even more notable in light of the reduction in high margin termination fees and float income. We generated a record $668 million of free cash flow for the year. On a per-share basis, free cash flow per share grew 16% in 2009 to $4.30 per share, compared with $3.70 per share in 2008. Our free cash flow per share was 17% higher than our adjusted earnings per share in 2009. These results reflect strong working capital management and consistent capital allocation. While we recognized that free cash flow per share will not grow at a level that far in excess of earnings each year, we do believe our model will provide free cash flow in excess of adjusted earnings over the long term.Now onto the segment results. The Payment segment generated 2% adjusted internal revenue growth in the quarter, with adjusted revenue of $513 million. On a year-to-date basis, adjusted revenue was $1.95 billion, up 1% over the prior year. We continue to see attractive growth in our Debit, Online Banking and Bill Payment businesses, which make up a majority of the Payment segment.Transaction volumes from our debit products continue to accelerate much more rapidly than the market. As an example, debit and network transactions grew with strong 24% in the quarter and 20% over the prior year. The above market growth rates are a result of strong integrated sales to our account processing base and the earlier adoption of debit by consumers served by our community-based institutions, who are still building up their monthly usage. The debit client base continues to expand at a healthy level, with over 200 client wins in 2009, which are larger in size and term that in the prior year. New bill payment sales were also strong with the signing of over 400 clients in 2009, many of which are competitive takeaways. While most of our clients transaction volume grew at double-digit rates in 2009, overall transaction volume growth for the year was somewhat muted by lower-than-anticipated volume at some larger clients. And also the acquisition of a remittance only client, which specifically impacted fourth quarter growth versus the same quarter last year.  We remain very bullish in that solutions set and the underlying revenue growth, which we can see today. Adjusted operating income for the Payment segment was $164 million in the quarter. Adjusted operating margin of 32.1% was up 80 basis points over the last year. For the year, segment adjusted operating income was up 7% to $670 million, and adjusted operating margin was up 170 basis points to 31.7%. The increase in adjusted operating margin in this segment for both the fourth quarter and year, was driven primarily by strong operating leverage in our Transaction-Based businesses and operational efficiencies from the CheckFree acquisition.The Financial Institution segment generated revenue of $497 million in the quarter, up 1% compared with the prior year. For the full year, revenue was down 3% to $1.94 billion compared to the prior year. Adjusted internal revenue was flat in the quarter and declined 4% for the year. Excluding a $7 million reduction in termination fees in the quarter, internal revenue growth would have been approximately 2%. And for the full year, excluding the $35 million decline in termination fees, internal revenue would have declined about 2%.The very low termination fees reflect slowdown in voluntary merger and acquisition activity among financial institutions that we have witnessed all year. Although we expect termination fees to remain at low levels in 2010, they will not be material drag on our revenue growth rate. In spite of the tough environment, we managed the segment well and finished the year strong. We continue to generate high-quality earnings in this the segment, reflecting the power of thousands of privilege relationships, market-leading products and proactive management. While adjusted revenue in the Financial segment declined by $50 million or 3% for the year, expenses in this segment declined by $74 million or 5%, leading to an increase in adjusted operating income for the period of $24 million to $569 million. These results drove 190 basis point expansion in margin to 29.3%. The strong margin improvement was driven by several factors, including strength in our Account Processing businesses and disciplined focus on operational efficiency, which serve to offset the negative impact of the reduction in high margin termination fees. For the quarter, operating margin in the segment increased 90 basis points to 28.5% compared with the prior year, due primarily to the strength in our recurring revenue, Account Processing businesses, strong license revenue from add-on products and renewals and operating efficiencies. These positive benefits were partially offset by the accrual of the incremental profit-sharing, continued expense actions to align our revenue, and cost in businesses, such as item processing and higher commissions and employee costs related to the very strong finish through the year. We continue to proactively manage capital expenditures, ending the year at $198 million, the same as last year's level or approximately 5% of adjusted revenue. We also recognized that capital expenditures are only one component of how we invest in our products and solutions, with labor and operating costs being the most significant element of our investment costs, a majority of which is  expensed directly to the income statement. Our strong fourth quarter free cash flow allowed us to repay $140 million of debt in the fourth quarter, of which $120 million was the pre-payment of our December 2010 debt payment and $475 million for the year.Net interest expense was $51 million for the quarter and $212 million for year. We expect that the combination of expired fixed rate interest rate hedges and debt reduction will reduced interest expense at least $15 million for 2010, subject to the timing of borrowings, repayments and other areas of capital deployment. We repurchased 1.1 million shares for $47 million in the quarter and more than 4.1 million shares in 2009, for a total of $175 million. As of year end, we had 2.2 million shares remaining in our repurchase authorization.2009 was the first year in our 25-year history that we did not make an acquisition, a clear sign of our capital discipline across the company. However, we will continue to evaluate potential acquisition that allow us to expand our solutions set and build scale. Our effective tax rate for the quarter was 38.3% and 38.1% for the year, which excludes the impact of a $7 million GAAP income tax benefit or $0.04 per share related to the final settlement of a CheckFree purchase accounting tax reserve in the third quarter, which also was excluded from adjusted EPS.  We anticipate our 2010 tax rate to approximate our 2009 rate of 38.1%. Now, I'll turn the call back over to Jeff.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Thanks, Tom. Fourth quarter sales, in December in particular, was strong across the spectrum of financial institutions in both new client wins and integrated sales to existing clients. In addition to winning more than our fair share in the community secto
componenttext: Thanks, Tom. Fourth quarter sales, in December in particular, was strong across the spectrum of financial institutions in both new client wins and integrated sales to existing clients. In addition to winning more than our fair share in the community sector, we provided new services to clients, including Bank of the West, First Bank and Wells Fargo, as evidence of our increasing penetration among larger financial institutions. As a result of our strong finish, we achieved exactly 100% of sales quota for the year. We actually achieved an incredible 250% of quota for the month of December, giving us even more revenue growth momentum entering 2010.Although our better-than-expected fourth quarter sales results have unexpectedly reduced pipelines, we remain encouraged by the breadth and depth of the sales opportunities we are pursuing going into the new year. We expect that the combination of new opportunities and enhanced go-to-market approach would lead to even better sales results in 2010. That said, we continue to expect long sales cycles and somewhat unpredictable timing of actual sales attainment throughout the year, given the external environment.As I mentioned upfront, we made great progress going to market as one Fiserv, with $42 million of integrated sales in the quarter, an increase of 40% over the prior year. We finished the full year with $117 million in integrated sales, 30% ahead of '09 and 36% ahead of 2008. The leading areas of integrated sales were in payments, customer channels, such as Internet banking and branch and efficiency-based products. Before I get to our 2010 outlook, let me update you on our view of the environment and our key priorities for the year. In 2009, there were 158 regulatory actions impacting 140 banks and 18 credit unions, well within our range of expectations for the year and slightly less than 1% of all institutions. This, combined with the very low level of organic acquisition, serves to slow the extrapolated decline rate of depository institutions in the U.S. in 2009. As we have now seen, the assets and accounts of failed institutions don't go away. They are almost always assumed by another institution. We are intimately involved with these activities and track closely the impact of these wins and losses on our client base.  Since the beginning of the acceleration and regulatory actions in 2008, our account processing client base is down a net of two clients, stated in terms of where the FI [financial institution] subject to the resolution, lands from a core account processing perspective. Given the size and diversity of our client base, we continue to believe that the net impact on our core account processing base, in terms of numbers of clients, will be about neutral over time and very similar to that of normal M&A activity. For 2010, we expect the number of regulatory actions to accelerate and to be within the range of 200 to 250, with actions likely tapering off towards the end of the year. We expect the noble activity in 2010 to remain at low levels, with some slight uptick possible towards the end of the year depending on the regulatory environment.Additionally, we believe that the number of institutions that switch their core account processing systems will, as we witnessed in 2009, remain at lower levels that we have seen historically. For context, we believe that the number of actual core account processing buying decisions made during the year dropped by about 30% from the 2008 level. Combining the fact that fewer institutions will likely switch their account processing with our substantially increased win percentage, over 50% of all core switchers chose Fiserv in 2009 versus 42% last year, should go well for us, given the size and diversity of our client base.We have three key priorities for 2010, when taken together, should position Fiserv to expand its industry-leading position and build long-term shareholder value. Our priorities are: First, to deliver positive internal revenue growth and meet our earnings commitments; second, to center the Fiserv culture on growth, leading to improved enterprise win rates and a higher share of our strategic products; third, to provide innovative solutions that increase differentiation and importantly, enhance results for our clients. Our outlook for 2010 is based on a core assumption that the environment will be generally similar to that of 2009, albeit, less volatile as we marched towards 2011. We expect financial institutions to continue to be pragmatic with their technology-spending decisions and that overall budgets will be in a range of flat to slightly up.However, we believe that spending may bias towards the second half of the year and expect new material client investments to be moderated against their business results. We also assume that discretionary M&A activity will again be low, given the number of likely regulatory actions, and therefore, termination fees will remain at an extremely low level.  Last, given the current interest rate outlook, we expect float revenue in 2010 to be similar to 2009.  We expect our 2010 adjusted internal revenue growth to be in a range of 1% to 3%, which should include stronger growth in the Payment segment. Our guidance for the year includes the impact of foreign currency, which should not be significant. Given market conditions, we expect 2010 adjusted earnings per share growth of 8% to 11% or in a range of $3.96 to $4.07, and compared with the $3.66 earned in 2009. We expect earnings to be stronger in the second half of the year due to our normal business cycle and the timing of revenue recognition from new sales wins. We expect the company adjusted operating margin will increase at least 50 basis points over the 28.7% achieved in 2009. We will continue to make investments in 2010 that support stronger competitive differentiation and higher levels of revenue growth. These investments include: Areas such as our Acumen account processing platform, small business services, person-to-person payments, biller network, integrated debit, Mobile Money and sales and account management. As always, we will balance our level of investment with our earnings commitments, adjusting our investment levels as necessary for changes in the market environment.We anticipate free cash flow will approximate operating earnings growth and increase 5% to 8% over the record level attained in 2009 of $668 million. Our integrated sales target for 2010 is $105 million, and our target for incremental operational effectiveness is $40 million. Based on reaching the 2010 target level phase, we will achieved our goal of $250 million of operational efficiences, a full year earlier that originally anticipated. Given our strong our performance in this area over the last several years, we will update you with the revised operational effectiveness goal at our 2010 Investor Day. We are pleased to have provided our owners with earlier access to that value.Finally, our 2010 guidance considers various scenarios for the allocation of capital, including internal investment, debt repayment, acquisitions and share repurchase. We will make actual capital allocations determination throughout the year, as appropriate, under the circumstances. 2009 was a challenging year by any definition. In the most difficult macroeconomic conditions in the last 70 years, we delivered record levels of earnings per share and free cash flow. As important, we continue to enhance the quality of our earnings, as seen through adjusted operating margin. We exceeded our integrated sales and operational effectiveness goals by a wide margin and continue to deepen the integration of our solutions and enhance how we go to market.We didn't expect it to be easy and it wasn't. The strength of our 20,000 associates to make it happen everyday, is one of our key differentiators. I'm proud of what our people have done over the last year to help our clients navigate the turbulence and find unique opportunities to win. This attribute, along with the leading technology solutions in the industry, forms our basis for optimism moving forward. While we expect 2010 to continue to be challenging, we are up to the task and more than ready for what lies ahead. With that, operator, let's open the line for questions.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Bryan Keane. [Credit Suisse]
componenttext: [Operator Instructions] Our first question will come from Bryan Keane. [Credit Suisse]

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I just wanted to ask about the record December sales. Jeff, do think that was the end-of-the-year budget flush? Or a little bit of a breakthrough in spending? Just help me understand that.
componenttext: I just wanted to ask about the record December sales. Jeff, do think that was the end-of-the-year budget flush? Or a little bit of a breakthrough in spending? Just help me understand that.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, Bryan, it's really a combination of a variety of factors. It is the end-of-the-year rush to get some things done that the institutions were clearly going to need in a year. And that was really complicated by those long sales cycles that we were talki
componenttext: Yes, Bryan, it's really a combination of a variety of factors. It is the end-of-the-year rush to get some things done that the institutions were clearly going to need in a year. And that was really complicated by those long sales cycles that we were talking about last year. And thankfully, they got another cut-off at the end of the year. The December 31 deadline made some of that stuff happening -- made some of that stuff happen. But we also saw, frankly, good demand for some of our replacement bill payment products and debit products and really just a lot of momentum from the flags that were planting all year that we've been talking about, our go-to-market approach, which led to the very strong sales. And again, the majority of those sales were not product-oriented sales. They were nice recurring revenue and multi-year kinds of agreements with both new clients and add-on services to existing clients.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Now, normally I would have thought that that will create a little bit of a spike in the first half of the year, but it sounds like it's going to be more spread out throughout the year. If you could just give us some color on that.
componenttext: Now, normally I would have thought that that will create a little bit of a spike in the first half of the year, but it sounds like it's going to be more spread out throughout the year. If you could just give us some color on that.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. The reason why, especially on these transactions that tend to be competitive takeaways, you've got the near-term license fees or the simple products that are add-on products to get put in a fairly short period of time. But for most of our revenue, a
componenttext: Sure. The reason why, especially on these transactions that tend to be competitive takeaways, you've got the near-term license fees or the simple products that are add-on products to get put in a fairly short period of time. But for most of our revenue, as you know, they tend to be client conversions. They take a fairly long amount of time. People can sign an agreement in December for something that doesn't expire until June or April or even September, depending on how long those conversions are, and we are able to recognize the revenue until a later point of time. So that's really -- we saw a lot of that in our sales in the month of December and really in the fourth quarter. And so because of our recurring revenue model, we can start to see how that's going to layer in.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I might have missed it, Tom, but did you give the license sales in professional services, I guess your year-over-year growth rate?
componenttext: I might have missed it, Tom, but did you give the license sales in professional services, I guess your year-over-year growth rate?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. Overall, Bryan, as we have been saying all the year, we had a good quarter as far as our license revenues go on the fourth quarter. They are up over the prior year, roughly around $6 million to $7 million over the fourth quarter of 2008. For the year
componenttext: Yes. Overall, Bryan, as we have been saying all the year, we had a good quarter as far as our license revenues go on the fourth quarter. They are up over the prior year, roughly around $6 million to $7 million over the fourth quarter of 2008. For the year though, our license fees are down 10% overall, just given environment so, that kind of a clarity there. Again, they're roughly around 5% of our total revenues, around $200 million for the year.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, can you -- I was a little surprise to see no acquisitions for Fiserv this year. Obviously, that's a little against history. Can you talk about what that pipeline looks like and your appetite to make acquisitions going forward?
componenttext: Jeff, can you -- I was a little surprise to see no acquisitions for Fiserv this year. Obviously, that's a little against history. Can you talk about what that pipeline looks like and your appetite to make acquisitions going forward?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Sure. We talked during the year that the biggest challenge that we had in thinking about acquisitions was, how to price transactions given what was going on in the market environment. And so frankly, it wasn't that we weren't active. Our teams were fairly
componenttext: Sure. We talked during the year that the biggest challenge that we had in thinking about acquisitions was, how to price transactions given what was going on in the market environment. And so frankly, it wasn't that we weren't active. Our teams were fairly active looking at a lot of different potential transactions. We just didn't see transactions that either made sense for us or that got over the finish line by the end of the year. We still see a lot of interesting opportunities especially in areas that take advantage of our network economics. So products that might be in the payments area, risk area of those kinds of things. And it -- just as importantly, acquisitions that take advantage of the scale of Fiserv. So we're looking -- but we maintain a pretty high standard in how we're going to allocate our capital and whether that's to share repurchase or acquisitions or to debt repayment. We view them all equally important, but I suspect you'll continue to see us pretty active in the acquisition market.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from David Koning. [Robert W. Baird]
componenttext: Our next question will come from David Koning. [Robert W. Baird]

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: You talked about EPS being a little more back half weighted, but I'm wondering a little bit on the revenue growth. You had great reacceleration this quarter, the comps actually gets even easier into Q1 '09. So I'm wondering if you expect that kind of grow
componenttext: You talked about EPS being a little more back half weighted, but I'm wondering a little bit on the revenue growth. You had great reacceleration this quarter, the comps actually gets even easier into Q1 '09. So I'm wondering if you expect that kind of growth to stay stable at that 2% level starting off the year? Or maybe if you could just talk a little bit about how you see growth throughout the year?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes. I think again, Dave, we're going to be -- we still anticipate a stronger second half, and some of that have to do with as with, as Jeff highlighted, the sales win and that our revenue's going to fall in, and the fact that we did have a very strong qu
componenttext: Yes. I think again, Dave, we're going to be -- we still anticipate a stronger second half, and some of that have to do with as with, as Jeff highlighted, the sales win and that our revenue's going to fall in, and the fact that we did have a very strong quarter from a Q4 standpoint. And generally, as you know, some of our businesses have typically -- our normal businesses have been a little stronger in the third and fourth quarter, if you look back at the last couple of years. So we're not going to comment on overall growth rates by quarter, so that's now how we manage the business. But I do think, again, the second half is going to be a little bit stronger than the first half of 2009.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And Dave, let me just add one thing. I do think you'll see year-over-year improvements. And again we're not going to give quarterly guidance. But  just given the trend that you've seen, we would expect to see, kind of, continuing improvements on a year-ov
componenttext: And Dave, let me just add one thing. I do think you'll see year-over-year improvements. And again we're not going to give quarterly guidance. But  just given the trend that you've seen, we would expect to see, kind of, continuing improvements on a year-over-year basis. But we do believe that based on what we've seen both in the pipeline, as well as what's closed, that we'll see, kind of, large deltas come in, in the second half of the year.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Corporate expense, kind of, climbed throughout 2009. I think it started out the year at, I guess, $16 million. It ended the year -- Q4, it was $22 million. Is that something that continues that -- that $22 million number? Or is going to settle back a litt
componenttext: Corporate expense, kind of, climbed throughout 2009. I think it started out the year at, I guess, $16 million. It ended the year -- Q4, it was $22 million. Is that something that continues that -- that $22 million number? Or is going to settle back a little bit?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think it's going to probably average out. We have a number of things from a corporate standpoint that we're doing, David. As you know during the year, regarding our initiatives around our branding, a lot of the cross company initiatives around our
componenttext: Yes, I think it's going to probably average out. We have a number of things from a corporate standpoint that we're doing, David. As you know during the year, regarding our initiatives around our branding, a lot of the cross company initiatives around our enterprise services, framework and other investments that we're making. So I think if you look at, from an average basis, that's a pretty good run rate as we head into 2010.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from John Kraft.[D. A. Davidson & Co]
componenttext: Our next question will come from John Kraft.[D. A. Davidson & Co]

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I was wondering if you might be willing to break out segment-wise, but maybe put some, sort of, brackets around the growth expectations by segment for 2010?
componenttext: I was wondering if you might be willing to break out segment-wise, but maybe put some, sort of, brackets around the growth expectations by segment for 2010?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Yes, I think again, John, Jeff, kind of, highlighted earlier in the script comment that we anticipate on the longer term. And again, our Payments segment is going to be a little bit higher than our Core Account Processing segment. Mainly because as you're
componenttext: Yes, I think again, John, Jeff, kind of, highlighted earlier in the script comment that we anticipate on the longer term. And again, our Payments segment is going to be a little bit higher than our Core Account Processing segment. Mainly because as you're aware in the Financial segment, we do have the Check Processing business in there. And the characteristics of that business are clearly different than what we have in our Payments segment around debit and bill payments. So over the haul, we're not going to give specific guidance by saying that we anticipate that, that segment is going to have a little higher growth characteristics than we will in the Financial segment.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then moving on to the new Acumen product. Can you talk about what specifically motivated the Christian Community Credit? And is there a pipeline that's pretty robust for that product once you've, kind of, signed the first one?
componenttext: And then moving on to the new Acumen product. Can you talk about what specifically motivated the Christian Community Credit? And is there a pipeline that's pretty robust for that product once you've, kind of, signed the first one?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: It's purely a technology play. This is a client who had actually been a Pfizer client and so knew as well. And it was time, from their standpoint, to move to a modern technology, real time job of 24/7 type platform. And we've had significant success up in
componenttext: It's purely a technology play. This is a client who had actually been a Pfizer client and so knew as well. And it was time, from their standpoint, to move to a modern technology, real time job of 24/7 type platform. And we've had significant success up in Canada. We're winning around 80% of the deals that we're engaged in. And we believe we talked about at Investor Day, this platform was actually designed in conjunction with a group of very large credit unions in the U.S., who -- we worked with them to design this platform to meet the needs of these larger credit unions, which actually is a space where we have done very poorly over the last several years. So this product was absolutely designed to meet the needs of clients who want to be outsourced with the most modern technology available, frankly, in the world. And Acumen is meeting those needs. That was the reason why they did it. And the pipeline is very robust. I would say just to manage expectations, it's early. This will be our first U.S. installation. But we believe that just based on the folks who helped us design the system, the user group, per se, who is involved in it that, just based on the names that are in that group, that I think we're going to see a lot of positive momentum in that over the next, probably 12 to 36 months.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We've had very well [indiscernible] -- I think Jeff highlighted this in the international market place. And we've had a number of wins in that particular area. So it does have a lot of momentum.
componenttext: We've had very well [indiscernible] -- I think Jeff highlighted this in the international market place. And we've had a number of wins in that particular area. So it does have a lot of momentum.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Jeff, if you could just repeat the comment you made? You said since the acceleration and regulatory actions in 2008, you've had equivalent of net to client lost[ph]. What was the comment?
componenttext: Jeff, if you could just repeat the comment you made? You said since the acceleration and regulatory actions in 2008, you've had equivalent of net to client lost[ph]. What was the comment?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We, not surprisingly each week, we pay attention to, of the institutions that are under a resolution. Are they our account processing client or not? And so if you go back to the middle of 2008 through the end of December, we are down two clients, which me
componenttext: We, not surprisingly each week, we pay attention to, of the institutions that are under a resolution. Are they our account processing client or not? And so if you go back to the middle of 2008 through the end of December, we are down two clients, which means that all of the 158 that were in 2009, and I think the 50 or so that were in 2008, if you take the clients and those that clients that assumed the institution. So if a Pfizer client assumes a Pfizer client, that's a neutral. And if a Pfizer client goes to a competitor's institution, who we don't do the core processing for, then we count that as a loss. If you add that all up, net of the low 200s, we're down two clients. And so the point that we're trying to make is that is actually not at all different than you would see if there was organic acquisition going on. And so net net, we're actually in pretty good shape. And that was the point we were trying to make.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Tien-Tsin Huang.[JP Morgan]
componenttext: Our next question will come from Tien-Tsin Huang.[JP Morgan]

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: This is David Cohen for Tien-Tsin. There's been obviously lots of news around government involvement with the banks and the latest proposal. I saw it sounds like there might be money going to community banks to help us lending. Would you talk about and ob
componenttext: This is David Cohen for Tien-Tsin. There's been obviously lots of news around government involvement with the banks and the latest proposal. I saw it sounds like there might be money going to community banks to help us lending. Would you talk about and obviously until anything gets set, it's hard to know. But what are some of the regulatory-related dynamics are for the banks and how that's going to affect you?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, I'll give it a shot. I mean there are a lot of, obviously, things going on as it relates to regulation. It changes to Reg E, the whole fee question, interchange, those kinds of things. So there's clear pressure. And I think the administration's prop
componenttext: Well, I'll give it a shot. I mean there are a lot of, obviously, things going on as it relates to regulation. It changes to Reg E, the whole fee question, interchange, those kinds of things. So there's clear pressure. And I think the administration's proposal to take some of the TARP money and take that 30 or so billion dollars and funnel it back to community-based institutions to try to jump start lending, I think those are very good things. I think the tone, at least, as we can see if the tone in Washington has become more favorable to community-based institutions. We think that's a good thing. But frankly, we believe that there's going to be a lot of energy around thinking about repricing within the institutions, how they priced DDAs, how do they price services and what will those implications be on the end consumer. From our perspective, we don't see that having a material impact on what we do. In fact, we find ourselves involved in these strategic discussions with the institutions and that we believe that there will be, not surprisingly, technology implications to these kinds of changes. And so we expect that, that will be generally positive to us in what we're thinking. And we think that the war for consumers at the institution level will actually put a premium on those technologies that are stickiest and most differentiating. That's one of the reasons why we're choosing to invest in a number of different initiatives so that we can help our clients be more differentiated as they face off to the consumer.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And how did the Item Processing business perform in the quarter?
componenttext: And how did the Item Processing business perform in the quarter?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: We don't give guidance by specific business. But clearly, as you're aware, that business check continues to decline anywhere from 5% to 7%. We continually have migration over to electronic. But that's been happening for a period of time. And we continue t
componenttext: We don't give guidance by specific business. But clearly, as you're aware, that business check continues to decline anywhere from 5% to 7%. We continually have migration over to electronic. But that's been happening for a period of time. And we continue to take the actions we need to do from an expense standpoint. But we continue to have a number of opportunities that are also from picking up more business as far as larger clients in that particular area that we continue to work on. But again, we continue to manage that business tightly. It definitely has got different characteristics as it's transitioning over to electronic. But we manage our expenses tightly. And we plan again some more sizable wins to be able to increase spent volume over our infrastructure that we have in that business.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And I think it's probably fair to say that the item processing business continued to pressure our growth rate in the fourth quarter as it did in each of the other quarters during the year. Absolutely.
componenttext: And I think it's probably fair to say that the item processing business continued to pressure our growth rate in the fourth quarter as it did in each of the other quarters during the year. Absolutely.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: It looks like the bill payment transactions and the e-Bills delivered may have decelerated. Am I looking at those numbers right? And is that something that we should expect to continue? Or could that pick back up as we go into 2010?
componenttext: It looks like the bill payment transactions and the e-Bills delivered may have decelerated. Am I looking at those numbers right? And is that something that we should expect to continue? Or could that pick back up as we go into 2010?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think as I, kind of, highlighted -- I'll turn this over to Jeff also. We had growth there of roughly 5% in the quarter for bill payment transaction. But I did put a little note down there that, I think, it's roughly been around 8%. We did have a client
componenttext: I think as I, kind of, highlighted -- I'll turn this over to Jeff also. We had growth there of roughly 5% in the quarter for bill payment transaction. But I did put a little note down there that, I think, it's roughly been around 8%. We did have a client that got acquired and we lost the remittance only volume. So from that standpoint, we had a decrease. But excluding that, it was around 8% on average. And what I'd say is that for the majority of clients that we have in bill payment, we're definitely seeing double-digit increases. We have some larger clients in that particular area of our business that were fairly flat for the year that kind of -- the volume and accounting increases weren't as great as what we anticipated. So the larger clients, we're growing as much. But the flags that we're planning, the majority of our clients there are growing in the double-digit area. And clearly I also highlighted in the debit area the growth of roughly 20% in transaction volumes that we've experienced in 2009. So with that, I'll turn that over to Jeff to see if he's got any other comments on that.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say that because right now, the concentration on -- and I'll just talk about e-Bill for a moment. There's a fairly large concentration of e-Bill utilization in the largest institutions. And so to the extent that the growth is muted at the larger i
componenttext: I would say that because right now, the concentration on -- and I'll just talk about e-Bill for a moment. There's a fairly large concentration of e-Bill utilization in the largest institutions. And so to the extent that the growth is muted at the larger institution level, as we've seen for the last couple of quarters, it has some interim impact on our growth rate in e-Bill. And e-Bill, we believe is a powerful driver of bill payment, moving forward. we like what we're seeing on the underlying trend basis. And we'll look forward to, hopefully in 2010, as the larger institutions put more energy on re-revving their growth rate, we think that will free up some of the pressure that exists on our e-Bill rate right now. Yes, there was a little bit of a deceleration but we don't find it any cause for a concern at this stage.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Ashwin Shirvaikar.[Citi]
componenttext: Our next question will come from Ashwin Shirvaikar.[Citi]

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Could you follow up and maybe talk about what you're seeing in January this year? Not sure if you could do that.
componenttext: Could you follow up and maybe talk about what you're seeing in January this year? Not sure if you could do that.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I will say is, I mean, obviously, we can't talk in any detail. But I would say is while the pipeline clearly was drained a bit in December, I've been positively surprised, that the level of current activity in January because one of the things that h
componenttext: What I will say is, I mean, obviously, we can't talk in any detail. But I would say is while the pipeline clearly was drained a bit in December, I've been positively surprised, that the level of current activity in January because one of the things that happened all last year, as we kept talking about the elongation of the sales cycles, and so even though there was a lot that came out of the pipeline in December, because those pipelines were so large, there's still a significant amount of activity out there. So it's one of the reasons why I remain very optimistic about the fact that we'll actually have higher absolute sales performance in 2010 than we did in 2009. It's really based on the stronger start that we see to the year versus where we were last year, and especially giving weight to how strong December was.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And could you comment on the pricing that you've seen on recent contract activity, both on the bill payment and debit side of things, as well as the account processing side of things?
componenttext: And could you comment on the pricing that you've seen on recent contract activity, both on the bill payment and debit side of things, as well as the account processing side of things?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I would say on bill payment and debit, really, there haven't been any material changes in the pricing environment. I mean, my overarching comment would be, there have been very few, if any, material changes in the pricing that we're seeing in the market.
componenttext: I would say on bill payment and debit, really, there haven't been any material changes in the pricing environment. I mean, my overarching comment would be, there have been very few, if any, material changes in the pricing that we're seeing in the market. I would say that we're still seeing a fair amount of sales activity on the debit and bill pay side as well as we talked about with over 600 wins in that area for us in 2009 and a lot of runway, moving forward. On the account processing side, the only thing I would say is, as I noted in our prepared remarks, there were about 30%, we think its preliminary, but we believe there's about 30% less switches occurring in 2009. And so there are fewer opportunities out there that are being chased. And that always increases the level of competitiveness across the industry. But again, probably the best news is, those of us who have been operating in this business for a long time, whether it's us or any of the other players, we've been dealing with the declining market for quite a while. And so at least, we believe people understand the importance of playing in a way that allows people to price things in a way that makes sense.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Just on margins and obviously you guys have done a good job with margins so far. But is there a structural limit to where margins can go? And two ways I look at this. One is you get some margin improvement each year just from existing margin and growth ra
componenttext: Just on margins and obviously you guys have done a good job with margins so far. But is there a structural limit to where margins can go? And two ways I look at this. One is you get some margin improvement each year just from existing margin and growth rate, I'm unsure they cross the two segments. Can each of those segment margins go up as well and what can you do with corporate expense?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I think as we've shown over the last -- as we highlighted in our script that our margins over the last three years have been up about 600 basis points. So I think one of the things you've got to remember is that the business model that we have does have a
componenttext: I think as we've shown over the last -- as we highlighted in our script that our margins over the last three years have been up about 600 basis points. So I think one of the things you've got to remember is that the business model that we have does have a lot of fixed costs in our infrastructure as we reshape the companies that we have, and so forth in the payments in our account processing and service bureau. Clearly, we have some incremental higher margins, one that additional business comes on. So I do continue to believe the we have opportunity to expand margins, going forward, clearly, because of that revenue model. And secondarily as we highlighted, we continued to have a lot of programs on the operational efficiency side. We've made very good strides in there. And I know I highlighted on Investor Day, some of the opportunities we still have for efficiency around data center and shared services and other things that we'll continue to work on in the company. I don't think you can say year-over-year, we're going to 200 basis points but our guidance for 2010 is 50 basis points plus and I think over the longer term, the model continues to have available leverage in it.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: So in the next couple of years, there really isn't a reason why you shouldn't get that, at least, 15 bps?
componenttext: So in the next couple of years, there really isn't a reason why you shouldn't get that, at least, 15 bps?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: That is our long-term guidance and there's always a number of investments that we like to make. And we always will monitor that very closely to meet our earnings commitments that we have as a company.
componenttext: That is our long-term guidance and there's always a number of investments that we like to make. And we always will monitor that very closely to meet our earnings commitments that we have as a company.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Brett Huff.[Stephens Inc.]
componenttext: Our next question will come from Brett Huff.[Stephens Inc.]

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Can you give me some color on how the conversation go as you guys succeed more often at larger and larger institutions? I understand it's usually a sale of an ancillary solution and things like that, but can you go through how those conversations go and h
componenttext: Can you give me some color on how the conversation go as you guys succeed more often at larger and larger institutions? I understand it's usually a sale of an ancillary solution and things like that, but can you go through how those conversations go and how you're being more successful?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Brett, when you say larger institution, what type of solution are you talking about?
componenttext: Brett, when you say larger institution, what type of solution are you talking about?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I guess, just generally. Like the example that's in my mind is the Wells Fargo note that you had in your press release, around the ACH business that you have. But it could be any.
componenttext: I guess, just generally. Like the example that's in my mind is the Wells Fargo note that you had in your press release, around the ACH business that you have. But it could be any.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The situation with any of the larger institutions, if you take the top, called the top 35 institutions in the U.S., we have enterprise-relationship management folks who are responsible for managing those relationships. And it's really a matter of getting
componenttext: The situation with any of the larger institutions, if you take the top, called the top 35 institutions in the U.S., we have enterprise-relationship management folks who are responsible for managing those relationships. And it's really a matter of getting in and understanding what the institutions have, what it is that we have that can meet those needs. But probably most important is, building credibility as a partner to those institutions so they trust you with the next alternative solution or the next problem that you can solve together. And one of the big benefits of acquiring CheckFree was, CheckFree had relationships with 21 of the top 25 institutions on bill payment and a variety of relationships that came out of the legacy character businesses. And so we have found ourselves, and to some extent, I think the enviable position of having great relationships at pretty important levels in these institutions. And they take time to work, but we find a fair amount of creativity in those institutions in working with us on a variety of our current and some of the solutions that we're working on today that are new and not even in market, looking at how can we do things with some of those folks, maybe in areas like P2P and analytics where we can work together to change some of the paradigms in the financial services product delivers system today. So it's a -- you can't give a precise answer but it's about relationship. These are big-time buyers of best of breed. And so you have to have the best products. You put those together and we find ourselves having a lot of conversations on a day-to-day basis.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then on the sales, I know that you spent a lot of time and effort trying to get your sales in a way that you'd like it. It sounds like -- you've obviously been paying dividends all year. When you look to 2010, you'd given us an integrated sales number
componenttext: And then on the sales, I know that you spent a lot of time and effort trying to get your sales in a way that you'd like it. It sounds like -- you've obviously been paying dividends all year. When you look to 2010, you'd given us an integrated sales number. But again, any color on what is the sales force going to be focused on at particular products, larger clients, cross sales, et cetera?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: To some extent, it depends on which segment of our sales force. Because we have our sales force, the sales force that works with the top five institutions in the U.S. does not look the same as the sales force that works with the community banking force. S
componenttext: To some extent, it depends on which segment of our sales force. Because we have our sales force, the sales force that works with the top five institutions in the U.S. does not look the same as the sales force that works with the community banking force. So to some extent, it depends on those segments of the base. However, what I would say is they're primarily focused on what solutions do we have that can help those clients to be most successful. And I'm sorry I have to give a little bit of that motherhood and apple pie answer, but that really is the answer. So what do we have in our portfolio that's going to help the clients. And the clients have been focused on areas around operational efficiencies. So things like source capture, some risk management solutions, things like that. Payments are big, very big news. There's a lot of energy around what can you do as these payment types begin to converge. A lot of discussion on P2P mobile. So, kind of, the ability to access -- I've been frankly surprised that the energy around mobile, where you're seeing the financial institutions well ahead really of the application capability that's in the market, but mobile is a big deal. And then for us, we're very focused on where we have solutions that we believe are strategic to the company and strategic to the client. So Internet banking, embedded with bill payment, with analytics capabilities, the ability to talk to consumers, where they are with targeted personalized messages, all around digital transformation. Those are very big deals that's why you're seeing 1,370 payment sales over the last two years. I'd like that to be substantially higher, moving forward. Because those kinds of solutions, not only are they strategic for the client, but they create sticky relationships between the consumer and that FI and that benefits us over the longer haul.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: You're talking about probably a better second half, in terms of revenues. But can you distinguish that potential ramp from revenue recognition versus do you have the same opinion in terms of sales? And I guess my question is, how are you handicapping, sor
componenttext: You're talking about probably a better second half, in terms of revenues. But can you distinguish that potential ramp from revenue recognition versus do you have the same opinion in terms of sales? And I guess my question is, how are you handicapping, sort of, bank spending more of signing deals in the second half versus today?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Well, unfortunately, the only basis I have to consider that is what we saw in 2009. And we saw much more in actual sales than in the second half of '09, really in the fourth quarter of '09 than we did in any other time in the year. So my guess is -- my pr
componenttext: Well, unfortunately, the only basis I have to consider that is what we saw in 2009. And we saw much more in actual sales than in the second half of '09, really in the fourth quarter of '09 than we did in any other time in the year. So my guess is -- my prognostication is that we will see higher levels of sales in 2010 back half than we will in the first half. So I think we'll see that actually follow for both revenue and sales.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Julio Quinteros.[Goldman Sachs]
componenttext: Our next question will come from Julio Quinteros.[Goldman Sachs]

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: I want to go back to the Analyst Day presentation of long-term performance characteristics slide, where on that slide, you guys had adjusted earnings per share of 11% to 18% for current than a normal target of 15% to 19%. If you're just trying to reconcil
componenttext: I want to go back to the Analyst Day presentation of long-term performance characteristics slide, where on that slide, you guys had adjusted earnings per share of 11% to 18% for current than a normal target of 15% to 19%. If you're just trying to reconcile that back with the 8% to 11% target for calendar 2010, are we looking at a subcurrent, kind of, a run rate here? Or is there something in the way that pieces are moving through the model that gets us to the 8% to 11% versus 11%, 18% that I was thinking. Is it more of a current run rate?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: From our standpoint, when we put that out, we try to talk about that as being how we believe we will perform on average over any three-year period. We will fall within that range. So you think about this year, we were negative one on our internal revenue
componenttext: From our standpoint, when we put that out, we try to talk about that as being how we believe we will perform on average over any three-year period. We will fall within that range. So you think about this year, we were negative one on our internal revenue growth and about 10% on EPS. This year we'd given guidance of 1% to 3%, which wraps the bottom end of that. And we've given guidance on adjusted EPS of 8% to 11%. So again, it wraps the bottom of it. What I would tell you is, we have a couple of things that we're paying a lot of attention to. And that is, there are competitive dynamics in the market right now that give us a lot of energy around investing in products, many of which we talked about today, whether they be our Acumen processing platform, our new integrated debit platform, P2P analytics to name a few, but that the importance of getting them into the market quickly and planting those flags because we see the clients want those kinds of services right now, has had us increase our investment to levels that are going to be higher than we would do if we were, kind of, normally running the business. So we are basically moving more investment into this period. And we believe that will lead to better revenue growth in 2011 and better earnings growth in 2011 because we're basically consolidating more investment into this period. And as a safety net, in the event that the world doesn't perform the way we believe it is, we'll have the ability to cut back on that. And as you know, most of our investment is not in the form of CapEx, it's in the form of OpEx, which runs through our P&L. So we bear the full cost of those investments in the year we make them or in the years that we make them. And that's the downside. The upside is, we get the leverage later on. And I would say the last thing that probably matters a lot to us is, given all of the uncertainty in the environment, we just don't see any reason to get ahead of ourselves. We want to put out numbers that we are very confident in. And then we will manage to those numbers as we see the environment shaping up as we get somewhere past February 2.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Our next question will come from Greg Smith. [Duncan Williams]
componenttext: Our next question will come from Greg Smith. [Duncan Williams]

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: Tom, you said that free cash flow should be above adjusted net or could be above adjusted net income over the long term? And I'm, kind of, wondering what accounts for that potentially permanent difference and if that's the case, is there maybe a better wa
componenttext: Tom, you said that free cash flow should be above adjusted net or could be above adjusted net income over the long term? And I'm, kind of, wondering what accounts for that potentially permanent difference and if that's the case, is there maybe a better way to even report adjusted net income to, sort of, reflect that?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: What I said, and as you know our history on this, Greg, has been very good. I know when you look back at '09 and '08 our free cash flow per share was roughly $4.30 per share in 2009. And our adjusted earnings, which is you know that's about the after-tax
componenttext: What I said, and as you know our history on this, Greg, has been very good. I know when you look back at '09 and '08 our free cash flow per share was roughly $4.30 per share in 2009. And our adjusted earnings, which is you know that's about the after-tax intangible amortization or the non-cash intangible amortization of $3.70. So that was significantly higher. And I think overtime, what I said is, we've got a great job in the working capital and CapEx area. We always have certain add-backs like share-based comp that are normally going to enhance your free cash flow over time over adjusted earnings. So I think all I'm saying is that over time, over the long haul, our free cash flow is going to grow at or above our adjusted earnings. And mainly because of the add-back of a share-based comp, the work we do around  our working capital, and really the capital discipline that we have on capital expenditures, which we just have that throughout our organization as you can see, we typically have less or about the same of CapEx as depreciation. So that's, kind of, where we're at with that.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: And then I guess, Jeff, is there any possibility or have you considered or are you considering repricing the online bill payment business just given the fact that you're getting killed on the float side?
componenttext: And then I guess, Jeff, is there any possibility or have you considered or are you considering repricing the online bill payment business just given the fact that you're getting killed on the float side?

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
componenttextpreview: The answer is we look at our pricing strategies on a fairly regular basis. And what I don't want to do, Greg, is make a short-term decision that we'll regret for many, many years to come. I don't think you'll run into too many people who think interest ra
componenttext: The answer is we look at our pricing strategies on a fairly regular basis. And what I don't want to do, Greg, is make a short-term decision that we'll regret for many, many years to come. I don't think you'll run into too many people who think interest rates will stay down at this level for an extended -- and I don't know what an extended period of time is, but for an extended period of time. And therefore, while we look at it, we're not highly motivated to switch that because as you know, the margin on floating comes relatively high. And so we just don't want to do something in the short run that will hurt us.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010

componenttext: Yes, it did. It was primarily on the Financial segment. You'll see a little bit larger predominance in that segment. But it went through financial payments and corporate mainly because of the number of employees that are in the Financial segment. So you'll see a higher proportion in that segment. That's why you saw a little higher expenses in that area.

headline: Fiserv Inc., Q4 2009 Earnings Call, Feb 02, 2010
